Recommendation R 52 - Hexagonal weights - Metrological and technical
requirements |year = 2004 |publisher = International Organization of Legal
Metrology |accessdate = 28 December 2012}}

 | standard = SI base unit quantity = Mass symbol = kg namedafter = units1 =
 | Avoirdupois inunits1 = â  pounds  The
 | avoirdupois pound is part of both United States customary system of units and
 | the Imperial system of units.

 | units2 = Natural units inunits2 = â  hertz  One kilogram at rest has an equivalent energy approximately
 | equal to the energy of photons whose frequencies sum to this value.
}} The 'kilogram' or 'kilogramme' (SI symbol: 'kg'), is the base unit of mass in
the International System of Units and is defined as being equal to the mass of
the International Prototype of the Kilogram ('IPK'). {{cite web
 | title = International prototype of the kilogram (IPK) url =
 | http://www.bipm.org/en/scientific/mass/prototype.html publisher =
 | International Bureau of Weights and Measures (BIPM) date = accessdate =
 | 2013-01-07
}} The avoirdupois (or international ) pound, used in both the Imperial system and U.S. customary
units, is defined as exactly , making one kilogram approximately equal to 2.2046
avoirdupois pounds.

The gram was originally defined in 1795 as the mass of one cubic centimeter of water at 4Â°C, making the kilogram equal to the mass of one
liter of water. The prototype kilogram, manufactured in 1799 and from which
the current kilogram is based has a mass equal to the mass of 1.000025
liters of water.

The kilogram is the only SI base unit with an SI prefix ("kilo", symbol "k") as
part of its name. It is also the only SI unit that is still directly defined by
an artifact rather than a fundamental physical property that can be reproduced
in different laboratories. Four of the seven base units in the SI system are
defined relative to the kilogram so its stability is important.

The International Prototype Kilogram was commissioned by the General Conference
on Weights and Measures (CGPM) under the authority of the Metre Convention
(1875), and is in the custody of the International Bureau for Weights and
Measures (BIPM) who hold it on behalf of the CGPM. After the International
Prototype Kilogram had been found to vary in mass over time, the International
Committee for Weights and Measures (CIPM) recommended in 2005 that the kilogram
be redefined in terms of a fundamental constant of nature. At its 2011 meeting,
the General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM) agreed in principle that
the kilogram should be redefined in terms of the Planck constant, but deferred a
final decision until its next meeting, scheduled for 2014.

The International Prototype Kilogram (IPK) is rarely used or handled. Copies of
the IPK kept by national metrology laboratories around the world were compared
with the IPK in 1889, 1948, and 1989 to provide traceability of measurements of
mass anywhere in the world back to the IPK.
headings: Stability of the international prototype kilogram
